title: ELA 7.2: Research Writing & Information Literacy
description: Learn how to ask powerful questions, find credible information, and synthesize it into a well-structured research paper.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Developing a Research Question
lessons.description: Understand the purpose of a research question and learn to narrow topics.

items: Understand the purpose of a research question.
Differentiate between a topic and a research question.
Learn how to narrow a broad topic into a focused, answerable research question.

sections.content: Screen 2: Concept - The Guiding Star of Your Research

A research project begins not with a topic, but with a question. A topic is broad (e.g., 'Ancient Egypt'). A research question is specific and guides your entire investigation (e.g., 'How did the geography of the Nile River influence the religious beliefs of ancient Egyptians?'). A good research question is not a simple 'yes' or 'no' question; it requires investigation and analysis to answer. It acts as your compass, keeping your research focused and on track.
The effect of climate change on polar bears.
How has the melting of Arctic sea ice over the past 20 years impacted the hunting patterns and population of polar bears?

sections.question: Which of the following is the best example of a focused research question?
options: What were the main causes of World War II?
How did the Treaty of Versailles contribute to the outbreak of World War II?
sections.correctAnswer: How did the Treaty of Versailles contribute to the outbreak of World War II?
sections.explanation: A strong research question is specific and requires analysis, not just a list of facts.

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Identifying Credible Sources
lessons.description: Learn to evaluate sources for credibility using the CRAAP test.

items: Differentiate between primary and secondary sources.
Define credibility and understand why it's important.
Learn to evaluate sources for authority, accuracy, objectivity, and currency (the CRAAP test).

sections.content: Screen 2: Concept - Not All Information is Equal

In the digital age, we are flooded with information. Information literacy is the skill of finding, evaluating, and using information effectively. A key part of this is determining if a source is credible, meaning it is trustworthy and reliable. Using non-credible sources can undermine your entire research project with misinformation.
When was it published? Is it up-to-date for your topic?
Does it directly relate to your research question?
Who is the author? What are their credentials? Are they an expert?
Is the information correct? Can it be verified with other sources?
Why was this information created? Is it to inform, persuade, entertain, or sell something? Is it biased?

sections.question: You find a website about the benefits of a new medicine, but it is sponsored by the company that makes the medicine. Which part of the CRAAP test should make you cautious?
sections.explanation: The key issue here is the purpose of the websiteâ€”it's trying to sell something, which introduces bias.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Taking Notes and Avoiding Plagiarism
lessons.description: Learn effective note-taking strategies and understand plagiarism.

items: Learn effective note-taking strategies (paraphrasing, summarizing, direct quoting).
Define plagiarism and understand its serious consequences.
Understand the importance of citing sources to give credit to the original author.

sections.content: Plagiarism is using someone else's words or ideas without giving them proper credit. It is a form of academic dishonesty. To avoid plagiarism, you must always cite your sources. This means keeping careful track of where you get your information as you take notes. The three main ways to incorporate information are by paraphrasing, summarizing, or using direct quotes.
Restating a passage from a source in your own words. You must still cite the original source.
Briefly stating the main points of a source in your own words. You must still cite the source.
Using the author's exact words, enclosed in quotation marks. Use this sparingly, only when the original wording is particularly powerful or precise.

sections.question: If you rewrite a sentence from a book in your own words for your paper, what must you still do?
options: Nothing, because it's in your own words
sections.explanation: Even if you use your own words, the idea came from someone else, so you must give them credit by citing the source.

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Outlining and Structuring the Paper
lessons.description: Understand thesis statements and research paper structure.

items: Understand the purpose of an outline as a blueprint for your paper.
Learn the basic structure of a research paper: introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion.
Develop a thesis statement that will guide your paper.

sections.content: The thesis statement is the most important sentence in your entire paper. It is a single sentence, usually at the end of your introduction, that states the main argument or point you are going to prove. Every single body paragraph in your paper should exist to support and prove your thesis statement.
Screen 3: The Structure of the Paper
Grabs the reader's attention, provides background information, and ends with the thesis statement.
Each paragraph focuses on one main idea that supports the thesis. It should start with a topic sentence and include evidence from your research.
Restates the thesis in a new way, summarizes the main points, and provides a final thought for the reader.

sections.question: What is the main purpose of a thesis statement?
options: To state the main argument of the paper
sections.correctAnswer: To state the main argument of the paper
sections.explanation: The thesis isn't a summary, but the specific argument that the rest of the paper will prove.

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Creating a Works Cited / Bibliography
lessons.description: Learn to create proper citations in MLA format.

items: Understand the purpose of a Works Cited or Bibliography page.
Identify the core elements needed for a citation (author, title, publication date, etc.).
Learn the basic format for citing a book and a website in MLA style.

sections.content: Screen 2: Concept - Giving Credit Where It's Due

A Works Cited or Bibliography page is a list at the end of your paper that provides the full details for every source you used in your research. It serves two main purposes: it gives credit to the original authors, and it allows your reader to find your sources for themselves. Different academic fields use different citation styles, such as MLA, APA, or Chicago. We will focus on the basics of MLA (Modern Language Association) style.
Author's Last Name, First Name. Title of Book. Publisher, Publication Year.
Author's Last Name, First Name. "Title of Web Page." Title of Website, Publication Date, URL. Accessed Date.

sections.question: What is the main purpose of a Works Cited page?
options: To show how many sources you used
To give credit to original authors and allow readers to find your sources
To make the paper look more professional
sections.correctAnswer: To give credit to original authors and allow readers to find your sources
sections.explanation: While it does show how many sources you used, its primary purpose is to give credit and provide a trail for other researchers.
